page.title: 07SHEEP FARMING
page.content: {Swaledale sheep}are kept on the fell. They are known locally as Blackface, and are mated November 20th onwards to lamb in late April. They are mainly brought into enclosed land for lambing. The wethers are sold for store or fat at{local marts}of Tow Law, St. John's Chapel, Barnard Castle and Hexham-fat lambs making about Â£30 in 1985. Swaledale ewes are kept on enclosed or "in bye" land and crossed with a {Leicester tup}to produce{mule lambs. Tups are loosed from November to end of December to lamb in April. These lambs are very popular with buyers coming from as far as Surrey every year. Gimmer lambs averaged Â£57 in 1985. {Suffolk tups}are crossed with mule ewes and the lambs sold fat-prices Â£36 1985.
